The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.

For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Product Notation in Monoids to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a Product Notation in Monoids involves the multiplication of elements within a monoid, which is a set equipped with an associative binary operation and an identity element. The definition of Product Notation in Monoids does not require the concept of a domain as used in the context of functions. The domain in function theory refers to the set of all possible inputs for which the function is defined, which is a different context from the operation within a monoid. In monoids, the focus is on the elements of the monoid and their associative multiplication, not on input-output mappings of functions. Therefore, the concept of a domain as defined for functions is not necessary for understanding or defining the product notation in monoids.
